description: Looking for a chill space to explore big ideas, challenge perspectives, and maybe catch a thought-provoking film? Moral Mondays are your weekly dose of open discussions, engaging debates, and movie nights that dive into the moral questions shaping our world. Whether you're a philosophy buff, a future leader, or just someone who loves a good conversation, there's a seat for you. No prep, no pressure—just bring your thoughts and an open mind. Every week, a new theme. There's always something to think about. Snacks provided. Opinions welcome. See you there?  |
title: Nov 3, 2025: Moral Mondays at Bryant Hall

description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=of7Hfd0bNFQ MONDAY NOV. 3rd 5:00 pm: 208 BRYANT HALL (public screening, FREE and open to all!) In OBSERVER, filmmaker Ian Cheney embarks on an experiment in which he brings a series of keen-eyed observers - scientists, artists, a hunter - to a range of locations around the world, often without telling them where they are going, and asks them simply to describe what they see. Oxford's own Aimee Nezhukumatathil, author and professor of English, was selected as one of the twelve "Observers" in this nature documentary, and you'll see her journey as she is unexpectedly, comically sent to Greenland in the middle of a Mississippi summer. This film debuted at the 2025 Copenhagen film festival and is not to be missed for anyone needing a reminder of the beauty still here on this planet. What unfolds is a deep exploration and celebration of the power of observation: what happens when you find new ways to sense and perceive the world around you? With customary whimsy and a small painted red square that Cheney brings on every journey, the film is an invitation to viewers to find beauty and meaning in even the most quotidian of locales. Award-winning director Ian Cheney will chat in-person with Aimee Nezhukumatathil after the film for an audience "talk back" session! https://www.observerfilm.org/meet-the-observers  |
title: Nov 3, 2025: OBSERVER: nature documentary screening  at Bryant Hall

description: Prof. Helvi Witek (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign) CSI Gravity: investigating mysteries in modern physics with black holes and gravitational waves Black holes, and the gravitational waves that their collision produces, are among the most exciting predictions of Einstein's theory of general relativity as they offer unique access to extreme gravity. We have come a long way since they were conceived of more than a century ago: this year we are celebrating 10 years of gravitational wave observations with LIGO, and I will give an overview in the first part of my presentation. This year also marks the 20th anniversary of numerical relativity simulations of coalescing black holes that have been crucial for the first LIGO detection, and I will share recent developments in the second part of my talk. I will then give a taster on how I use numerical relativity simulations to investigate long-standing puzzles in fundamental physics ranging from dark matter to the very nature of gravity itself.  |
title: Nov 4, 2025: Physics Colloquium: Prof. Helvi Witek at Lewis Hall

description: Abstract Let A and B be subsets of an abelian group G with |B| ≤ |A|. Their sumset A + B is the subset consisting of all a + b with a ∈ A and b ∈ B. There are many results along the lines of small sumset implies structure. For instance, when |A + B| < |A| + 2|B| − 3 with G equal to the integers, then A and B must each be large subsets of arithmetic progressions (having common difference) with very precise bounds on just how large. This result derives from classical work started by Freiman, but decades later it is still an open question to fully extend it to an analogous result for G cyclic of prime order p. In this talk, I will overview the basic situation and methods used in this regime, and then focus on recent work attaining such precise inverse structure for sumsets with very high density |A + B| = (1 − ϵ)p.  |
location: High Density Modulo p at Hume Hall
title: Nov 5, 2025: Combinatorics Seminar - The Freiman 3k − 4 Theorem at High Density Modulo p at Hume Hall

description: Are you looking for powerful ways to engage students, deepen critical thinking, and foster communication skills? In this workshop, Dr. DiBiasie-Sammons will introduce participants to Reacting to the Past (RTTP), an immersive, role-playing pedagogy that pushes students out of their comfort zones and into the shoes (or sandals!) of historical figures. Students debate, scheme, strategize, and lead their way through pivotal moments in history. This interactive session will cover the fundamentals of Reacting to the Past including its pedagogical goals, classroom structure, and implementation strategies. Dr. DiBiasie-Sammons will also share survey data on its self-reported effectiveness in her own classes. But we won’t just talk about RTTP — participants will experience a short gameplay session and explore how Reacting can be adapted across a wide range of disciplines. Whether your field is science, math, history, or the arts, there’s a game for you. Come ready to play, reflect, and reimagine what learning can look like. Lunch will be provided for registered participants. Please register here by October 30.  |
title: Nov 6, 2025: Engaging Students through Reacting to the Past: Active Learning in the College Classroom at J.D. Williams Library

description: How many of us are good and virtuous people? How many are truly bad? Our invited speaker claims that psychology has an answer: We're almost all somewhere in the middle. Dr. Christian Miller of Wake Forest University offers a philosophical, psychological, and theological analysis of human character. He offers emprical evidence about how most people's character is suprisingly inconsistent as well as some thoughts for how we can nevertheless hope to improve. Join us Thurs, Nov. 6 for wine and cheese at 5pm in Bryant Gallery followed by Dr. Miller's talk and Q&A from 6-7pm.  |
title: Nov 6, 2025: "The Character Gap" - Invited Ethics Talk at Bryant Hall

description: Rumours of Fleetwood Mac, the world’s finest tribute to Fleetwood Mac, returns to the stage celebrating the very best of Fleetwood Mac’s iconic music. Channeling the spirit of Fleetwood Mac, and performing hits such as “Go Your Own Way,” “Dreams,” and “Rhiannon,” note for note, Rumours of Fleetwood Mac offers a unique and authentic opportunity for fans, both old and new, to rediscover the songs and performances that have ensured Fleetwood Mac’s place as one of the most loved and best-selling bands of all time. Rumours of Fleetwood Mac has now performed to over 950 THOUSAND Fleetwood Mac fans across the world and racked up more than 89 MILLION views on YouTube. Formed back in 1999, Rumours of Fleetwood Mac is the ultimate tribute to one of rock and roll’s most remarkable groups—now recognised globally as the ”Finest Fleetwood Mac Concert Experience” and personally endorsed by founding Fleetwood Mac member Mick Fleetwood!  |
location: Gertrude C. Ford Center for the Performing Arts
title: Nov 6, 2025: Rumours of Fleetwood Mac at Gertrude C. Ford Center for the Performing Arts
